Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Numerical Simulations of Merging Black Holes and Neutron Stars
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research by a group at California State University, Fullerton (CSUF) to model merging black holes and neutron stars and the gravitational waves they emit. Merging black holes and neutron stars are among the most promising sources of gravitational waves for the Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (Advanced LIGO), and black hole-neutron star mergers are one possible source of short, hard gamma-ray bursts. This research program uses supercomputers to numerically solve Einstein's equations of general relativity for i) merging black holes, especially cases (such as mergers with black holes that are spinning nearly as rapidly as possible) that have not been previously explored, and ii) a black hole, spinning nearly as rapidly as possible, that merges with a neutron star, tearing the star apart.

Almost a century after Einstein first predicted their existence, gravitational waves---ripples of spacetime curvature---are poised to open a new window on the universe. Advanced LIGO, an NSF-supported project, is nearing completion and will soon begin searching for gravitational waves from black holes, neutron stars, and other sources, such as supernovae. By predicting the gravitational waves emitted by merging black holes and neutron stars, this research program will increase the reach of Advanced LIGO and will help us to learn as much as possible about LIGO's astronomical sources. Through their participation in this program, students at CSUF, a primarily undergraduate- and Hispanic-serving institution, will learn transferable research and computational skills while playing important roles in preparing for the first direct detections of gravitational waves, an imminent discovery that could dramatically alter our understanding of the universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2015, a century after Einstein predicted their existence, the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) discovered gravitational waves—ripples of warped spacetime—as they passed through Earth. The waves came from a distant pair of black holes as they spiraled together and merged. This discovery inaugurated the era of gravitational-wave astronomy, giving us a new sense to observe the universe.

In this project, researchers from California State University, Fullerton (CSUF) used supercomputers to calculate the expected gravitational waves from different pairs of merging black holes and neutron stars. Their calculations helped LIGO to detect as many gravitational waves as possible and to learn as much as possible about the detected waves' sources.

We used the Spectral Einstein Code [black-holes.org/SpEC.html] to simulate merging black holes and the gravitational waves they emit. By predicting the gravitational waves, we helped LIGO know what to expect; knowing what to "listen for" helped LIGO be able to find fainter waves from sources that are farther away, similarly to how you can hear a familiar voice across a noisy, crowded room.

We focused much of our attention on simulations with rapidly spinning black holes, which could be among the merging black holes that LIGO observes but which are especially challenging to simulate. We developed and used improved methods that let us calculate the gravitational waves from merging black holes with spins almost as fast as a single black hole can spin—closer to this spin limit than any previous calculation. Our results from these simulations helped to improve the approximate waveform models that LIGO uses to search its measurements for gravitational waves, extending them to faster black-hole spins. We also found that the merging black holes in our simulations turned out to always spin slower than the theoretical spin limit, even though this limit has only been shown to be true for single, isolated black holes.

We used our improved methods to predict the gravitational waves emitted when a black hole and neutron star merge. We used two approaches. First, we predicted the gravitational waves from two merging black holes, using a small black hole with no spin to "mimic" the neutron star. The calculated waveforms do not include effects of the neutron star matter but still are more accurate than other, approximate waveform models. Second, we began exploring how to apply our improved methods to simulations of a black hole tearing apart a neutron star that include matter effects.

When LIGO detected gravitational waves for the first time, we responded by simulating merging black holes with sizes and spins consistent with LIGO's estimates. We compared our predicted gravitational waves to LIGO's measurement, finding excellent agreement. We used our calculations to create a movie showing what the merging black holes would have looked like up close. To make sure that results from our computer calculations were correct, we compared one of our gravitational-wave predictions to a prediction by collaborators at the Rochester Institute of Technology, who independently simulated the same merging black holes, but with a completely independent computer code. We found that our results agreed well. 

Undergraduate and master's student researchers from CSUF, a primarily undergraduate- and Hispanic-serving institution, directly participated in the supported activities. In particular, these students played important roles in the discovery of gravitational waves while learning research and computational skills that they will take with them in their future careers. Reflecting CSUF's diversity, many of the student researchers participating in this project are from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in science. Our group's activities for this project included a strong outreach program, where we shared the excitement of gravitational-wave science with our local community, through presentations at schools and community colleges, public lectures, and interviews with the local media.
